Research Paper A new highly efficient NHC/Cu(I) catalyst system for the Ullmann-type N-arylation reactions Guiyan Liu Writing – review & editing Methodology Investigation Conceptualization a b ⁎ Qi Ding Writing – original draft Data curation a Huixin Zhang Formal analysis Data curation a Jiayi Chen Validation a Ke Wang Supervision a Yongfei Zeng Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition Conceptualization a ⁎ a College of Chemistry, Tianjin Key Laboratory of Structure and Performance for Functional Molecules, Tianjin Normal University, Tianjin, 300387, PR China College of Chemistry Tianjin Key Laboratory of Structure and Performance for Functional Molecules Tianjin Normal University Tianjin 300387 PR China aCollege of Chemistry, Tianjin Key Laboratory of Structure and Performance for Functional Molecules, Tianjin Normal University, Tianjin, 300387, PR China b Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry (Ministry of Education), College of Chemistry, Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, PR China Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry (Ministry of Education) College of Chemistry Nankai University Tianjin 300071 PR China bKey Laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry (Ministry of Education), College of Chemistry, Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. A novel N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligand precursor, o-Phen-L, based on 1,10-phenanthroline was designed and synthesized. This Imidazole salt was characterized by NMR spectroscopy and elemental analysis. The performance of o-Phen-L as a ligand has been evaluated. o-Phen-L coexisted with CuI to form a highly efficient catalytic system for the Ullmann type N-arylation reactions of (hetero)aryl chlorides and azoles. This catalytic system shows broad functional group tolerance and can provide the desired coupling products with high to excellent yields (80–98%) under mild conditions. Graphical abstract An NHC/CuI catalyst system for the Ullmann-type N-arylation reactions was developed. This NHC/CuI catalyst system was found to be efficient for the N-arylation reactions of (hetero)aryl chlorides and azoles with low catalyst loading under mild conditions. Image, graphical abstract Keywords N-heterocyclic carbene N-arylation reactions (Hetero)Aryl chlorides Azoles Copper(I) Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The copper catalyzed Ullmann coupling reaction has been widely used to construct CN bonds since its first report in 1903 [1]. Traditional Ullmann reaction conditions typically require harsh reaction conditions, such as high temperatures, strong bases, extended reaction times, and excessive copper sources. The introduction of ligands not only enhances the solubility of Cu catalyst in solution, but also enhances the catalytic activity of Cu catalyst, leading to a significant increase in reaction rate and yield [2-4]. In the presence of ligands, the reaction can proceed smoothly under relatively mild conditions with only a catalytic amount of Cu catalyst [5-10]. Therefore, developing stable and highly active ligands has always been a direction of effort for scientists. N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs), are a class of heterocyclic species containing a carbene carbon and at least one nitrogen atom within the ring structure [11]. The inherent σ-donor ability of NHCs makes them excellent ligands for transition metals and have wide applications in some of the most important catalytic conversions in the chemical industry [12,13]. Since its first application in homogeneous catalysis in 2001, NHC/Cu catalytic systems have been extensively studied and employed for catalysis due to their stable performance, low cost, and low toxicity [14-18]. NHC ligands not only serve as σ-donors, and π-interactions also exist between copper and NHC ligands [19-21]. In the past decades, various NHCs ligand precursors are designed, synthesized and used in copper catalytic systems [22]. However, so far, only a few NHCs ligands have been reported for copper catalyzed N-arylation reaction of aryl halides and azoles, and the reaction substrates are mostly limited to highly active aryl iodides and aryl bromides, while less active aryl chlorides are difficult to carry out in most reaction systems [23-27]. This greatly limits their application in industry. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop an efficient NHCCu catalyst system for N-arylation reaction of (hetero)aryl chlorides and azoles. Herein, a novel NHC ligand precursor (o-Phen-L), based on 1,10-phenanthroline is reported in order to overcome the above shortcomings. The carbene formed by o-Phen-L have stronger electron donating proper-ties, which can better stabilize the metal center. The new highly efficient NHC/Cu(I) catalyst system formed by o-Phen-L and CuI can efficiently catalyze the N-arylation reaction of (hetero)aryl chlorides with azoles under mild conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of 1,10-phenanthroline-2-carbaldehyde 1 To a flask were added SeO2 (1.3 g, 11.7 mmol), 1,4-dioxane (20 mL), and a few drops of water. After the solution was refluxed for a few minutes, 2-methyl-1,10-phenanthroline (1.3 g, 6.9 mmol) was slowly added. The mixture then continuing refluxed for 3 h. Then, the hot solution was filtered and the solvent was removed in vacuum. The resulting residue was dissolved in CH2Cl2, washed with water (3 × 30 mL), dried over Na2SO4 and concentrated under vacuum to give a brown solid. First, the compound 1 was synthesized from 2-methyl-1,10-phenanthroline by an oxidation reaction. Then, compound 1 reacted with 2,6-diisopropylaniline to form the imine compound 2. Finally, o-Phen-L was obtained by the condensed ring reaction between the compound 2 and paraformaldehyde, with a yield of 60%. It was characterized by NMR spectroscopy (see Supporting Information). 3.2 Catalytic activity o-Phen-L (5 mol%) was employed as a ligand for copper-catalyzed Ullmann reaction of 2-chloroquinoline (0.2 mmol) with imidazole (0.24 mmol) (Table 1 ). First, when Cs2CO3 was employed as a base at 80 °C, different solvents were selected, including 1,4-dioxane, DMF/H2O=1:1, and acetonitrile. After 3 h, lower yields of 30%, 20%, and 35% were achieved, respectively (Entries 1–3). When the reaction was carried out in DMF, an excellent yield (98%) was obtained (Entry 4). Then, DMF was used as a solvent to test the efficiency of different bases. After 3 h, the product yields obtained using K2CO3, K3PO4, and NaOH were 60%, 67%, and 83%, respectively (Entries 5–7). Undoubtedly, the performance of Cs2CO3 is superior to all other bases used. Finally, we chose DMF as the solvent and Cs2CO3 as the base in an attempt to lower the reaction temperature. When the temperature drops to 60 °C, the yield is only 70% (Entry 8). Considering energy, efficiency, and yield issues, we ultimately chose 80 °C as the optimal reaction temperature. In addition, comparative experiment was conducted to elucidate the importance of ligands. The results showed that only 10% yield was achieved in the absence of o-Phen-L (Entry 9). Then, we expanded the reaction to larger scope of substrates to prepare the quinoline N-heterocyclic azoles under optimal reaction conditions. Representative 2-chloroquinoline was chosen to react with various azoles (Table 2 ). Compared to the excellent yield of 98% for imidazole and 1,2,4-triazole exhibit slightly lower activity, but still provide higher yield (85%). For challenging substrates containing steric hindrance groups, such as 4-phenylimidazole, 4-methylimidazole, 2-methylimidazole, 2,4-dimethylimidazole, benzimidazole, and 1,2,3-benztriazole, they can also react smoothly with 2-chloroquinoline to provide the desired products with a yield of 80–90%. Meanwhile, a variety of electron-rich and electron-poor chloroquinoline derivatives were tested. In all cases, the corresponding N-heterocyclic azoles were achieved in high to excellent yields (80%−98%). With the above success, we sought to further expand the coupling reactions of a variety of heteroaryl chlorides with imidazole, 2,4-dimethylimidazole, or benzimidazole (Table 3 ). We found that 2‑chloro-6-fluoropyridine and 2‑chloro-4-cyanopyridine can react well with imidazole, 2,4-dimethylimidazole, or benzimidazole, achieving excellent yields (95%−98%). In addition, 2‑chloro-3- methylpyridine with steric hindrance can also coupled with imidazole to give the corresponding N-arylated products with high yield. We are pleased to note that the catalytic system remains highly efficient when using pyrimidine derivatives such as 2‑chloro-5-methylpyrimidine, 2‑chloro-4,6-dimethylpyrimidine, and 4‑chloro-2,6-dimethylpyrimidine as reaction substrates. In order to better demonstrate the superiority of this new catalytic system, a comparison was made with the currently reported copper catalytic system (Table 4 ). Compared with other reported copper catalyst systems [26,28-32], the new NHC/Cu(I) catalyst system has obvious advantages. 3.3 Synthesis of Cu-NHC complex In order to study the nature of the catalytically competent species, we attempted to synthesize the Cu-NHC complex. As shown in Scheme 2 , Cu-NHC complex was prepared by reacting commercially available CuI with o-Phen-L using N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) as a solvent in the presence of Cs2CO3. The Cu-NHC complex was characterized by NMR spectroscopy (see Supporting Information). 3.4 Catalytic activity of Cu-NHC complex Then, the catalytic activity of the Cu-NHC complex was investigated. As shown in Table 5 and Table 6 , when the Cu-NHC complex (1 mol%) was employed as a catalyst for the Ullmann reaction of (hetero)aryl chlorides (0.2 mmol) with azoles (0.24 mmol), the complex exhibited high reaction activity. After 1.5 h of reaction at 80 °C, all products were obtained with high to excellent yields (83%−98%). 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have developed a new highly efficient NHC/Cu(I) catalyst system for the N-arylation reactions of (hetero)aryl chlorides and azoles. This catalyst system can not only tolerate a wide range of functional groups under mild conditions, but also couple hindered substrates. We believe that this is very important for laboratory research and industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: A novel N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligand precursor, o-Phen-L, based on 1,10-phenanthroline was designed and synthesized. This Imidazole salt was characterized by NMR spectroscopy and elemental analysis. The performance of o-Phen-L as a ligand has been evaluated. o-Phen-L coexisted with CuI to form a highly efficient catalytic system for the Ullmann type N-arylation reactions of (hetero)aryl chlorides and azoles. This catalytic system shows broad functional group tolerance and can provide the desired coupling products with high to excellent yields (80–98%) under mild conditions.
